nealrichardson commented on pull request #6734: ARROW-8222: [C++] Use bcp to make a slim boost for bundled build
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/6734
 
 
   This patch switches our bundled boost ep to use a slimmer version of boost, which was built like this:
   
   ```
   curl -L https://dl.bintray.com/boostorg/release/1.71.0/source/boost_1_71_0.tar.gz > boost_1_71_0.tar.gz
   tar -xzf boost_1_71_0.tar.gz
   cd boost_1_71_0
   ./bootstrap.sh 
   ./b2 tools/bcp
   cp dist/bin/bcp bcp
   ./bcp system.hpp filesystem.hpp regex.hpp config build boost_install headers log predef boost_1_71_0
   du -h -d 1 boost_1_71_0
   tar -czf boost_1_71_0.tar.gz boost_1_71_0/
   ```
   
   The resulting tarball is 10mb, much less than 113mb of the full boost but larger than the 800k I suggested in the ticket. This is because in order to build regex and filesystem, we need `config build boost_install`, which add some weight. `log` is necessary because I'm running a debug build (I think that's why at least), and `predef` is needed by log apparently. 
   
   At this point, this is a proof of concept, but I at least wanted to run all of our builds with this and see how it goes, as well as get feedback. Outstanding questions/to-dos that I'm aware of:
   
   * [ ] Decide where to host the boost artifact and what to call it. It works as is, but I'm sure there will be opinions.
   * [ ] Check in a proper build script
   * [ ] Determine how/where to run the script to build and upload a new version. My thought is crossbow: to update the boost version or change what's included in the bundle, edit the script (part of apache/arrow) and run an on-demand build via PR comment.
   * [ ] See if we can pare back the dependencies included in the bundle. I iteratively added things like config and build in order to get a successful build, but maybe we can pull some out.
   * [ ] See if `log` is required only when we do a debug build, and if so, decide whether we want to make a debug build of boost libraries when we do an arrow debug build. Dropping `log` would save another 20-25%.

fields.description:
We don't use much of Boost (just system, filesystem, and regex), but when we do a bundled build, we still download and extract all of boost. The tarball itself is 113mb, expanded is over 700mb. This can be slow, and it requires a lot of free disk space that we don't really need.

[bcp|https://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_72_0/tools/bcp/doc/html/index.html] is a boost tool that lets you extract a subset of boost, resolving any of its necessary dependencies across boost. The savings for us could be huge:

{code}
mkdir test
./bcp system.hpp filesystem.hpp regex.hpp test
tar -czf test.tar.gz test/
{code}

The resulting tarball is 885K (kilobytes!). 

{{bcp}} also lets you re-namespace, so this would (IIUC) solve ARROW-4286 as well.

We would need a place to host this tarball, and we would have to updated it whenever we (1) bump the boost version or (2) add a new boost library dependency. This patch would of course include a script that would generate the tarball. Given the small size, we could also consider just vendoring it.
fields.summary: [C++] Use bcp to make a slim boost for bundled build

comments.body:
> We would need a place to host this tarball

You can host it as an artifact in a GitHub release. So we could put the bcp generator script in the Arrow repo and then use it to create the release artifact in a for-this-purpose GitHub repo

To collect some anecdotal evidence about problems with the current boost_ep. It seems the entire boostorg has some kind of rate limiting issue on Bintray and trying to access e.g. https://dl.bintray.com/boostorg/release/1.72.0/source/boost_1_72_0.tar.gz yields 403 Forbidden. So all the more reason to host our EP artifact on GitHub or some other place within our agency
